bullets.text: Machine learning involves teaching computers to learn from data.
It focuses on learning patterns rather than explicit programming rules.
This allows models to make predictions on new, unseen data.
Trained on labeled data, where inputs are paired with correct outputs.
Example: Identifying emails as spam or not spam.
The model learns patterns to predict outcomes for new data.
Common algorithms include decision trees, Support Vector Machines (SVMs), and neural networks.
System finds patterns and structures in data without explicit labels.
Example: Clustering customers into groups based on purchasing behavior.
K-means is a classic algorithm used for clustering.
An agent learns by interacting with an environment.
Learning occurs through feedback or rewards for actions taken.
Applications include training AI to play video games or control robots.
Overfitting: Model memorizes training data, leading to poor performance on new data.
Bias: Occurs when training data is unbalanced or unrepresentative.
Addressing these challenges is crucial for reliable model performance.
Healthcare: Used for disease prediction and diagnosis.
Finance: Applied in fraud detection and risk assessment.
Automotive: Essential for object recognition in self-driving cars.
The next lecture will cover how to evaluate machine learning models.
Key metrics include accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score.
These metrics are vital for understanding model performance and limitations.
